please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeBoris Johnson is set to give a pm press conference today confirming England’s lockdown can be eased on May . The Prime Minister is expected to announce that England can enter ‘Step Three’ of the roadmap he first set out in February. That means reopening pubs and restaurants indoors, letting family and friends stay overnight and reopening foreign travel. Hugging between friends and family also looks set to be allowed for the first time in  months, while steam rooms at spas can reopen. Final details were being signed off on Monday morning followed by a call with the Tory Cabinet. While nothing has been confirmed yet by Downing Street, we know the broad picture thanks to the roadmap itself and previous government announcements. So here’s our best guess of what you might be able to expect.  Hugging allowed Family and friends from dferent bubbles are expected to be allowed to hug again for the first time since March . With more than half of Brits having at least one vaccine dose, the PM is expected to say people should use their common sense. Broader social distancing rules, including in public venues like pubs and restaurants, will remain until at least June .But Cabinet Office minister Michael Gove confirmed the plan is to restore hugging from May  between friends and family - as first reported in The . “Friendly contact - intimate contact - between friends and family is something we want to see restored,” he told the BBC.  Overnight stays permitted If all goes to plan, Step Three will allow people from dferent bubbles to meet indoors from May  for the first time since the turn of the year. Groups of up to six people or two households - whichever is larger - will be allowed to meet in an indoor setting. This means that for the first time since the January lockdown, you can visit family where in England and stay the night . It’s likely government guidance on sensible social distancing, cleaning and ventilationwill remain.   Pubs can open indoors The rule of six indoors applies equally to hospitality venues such as pubs, restaurants and cafes. This indicates they will be allowed to open indoors from May  for the first time since the New Year. As with private homes, there will still be a maximum gathering size of six people or two households. Pubs will also be table service only, although there is no need to order a “substantial meal” with a drink any more.   Up to  people can gather outdoors The current limit of six people or two households on outdoor gatherings is likely to be removed at Step . Instead, there will only be a legal limit of  people for outdoor gatherings, except for some organised events as outlined below. This will mean large groups are once again allowed to gather in parks like last summer.  Domestic holidays can resume Currently, only self-contained holiday accommodation can open in England - and people can only stay with their own bubble. Now that you can stay overnight with people from dferent bubbles, hotels, BBs and other holiday venues like hostels are expected to reopen. This essentially means England’s domestic tourism industry is allowed to be back in business.   Foreign travel can resume From May , the legal ban on taking a holiday outside the UK is set to be lted and travel will be allowed. However, Brits ing from the vast majority of countries will have to isolate on their , either at home or in a £,-a-head hotel. Only ‘green list’ countries will be exempt from this and there are currently only a tiny handful of countries on the list, including Portugal and Israel. Most of the countries on the UK’s green list still require Brits to isolate when they get to that country, making holiday plans worthless. However, restrictions are widely expected to ease quite quickly as we move into June and July.  No cap on mourners at funerals The cap on mourners at funerals is set to be axed ahead of schedule when England enters Step Three from May . Currently funerals can only have  attendees while wakes are limited to  - a limit that was maintained for Prince Philipaposs memorial service. This limit was set to be reconsidered in step four of the roadmap, but the government has brought it forward. Instead of a -person limit, venues will decide how many people can attend safely while still keeping up social distancing rules. That means two metres between mourners, or one metre plus mitigations like masks, screens and ventilation. The new rules will apply to both indoor and outdoor services - but not wakes .   Larger events can start going ahead Fans canto sports fixtures in Step Three, with outdoor venues permitted capacities of , people or half-full, whichever is lower. In the largest outdoor seated venues, where crowds can spread out, up to , people will be able to attend, or grounds can be a quarter-full, whichever is fewer. Fans can attend larger performances and sporting events indoors, with capacities of , people or half-full, whichever is fewer. Other events have already been taking place - with bigger crowds and no social distancing - but theyaposre part of a special pilot scheme and people must get negative tests to enter.

title: real story local elections its
story: NewsopinionThe real story of the local elections - and why its bad news for Boris JohnsonOne extra MP makes very little dference compared to  directly-elected mayors, as the PM is about to find out, says Fleet Street FoxmirrorShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  MAY Newsopinion" %, rgba, rgba, url"Get US and UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeBin collections make the headlines only when they go wrong. But done well - regular, competent, reliable - they can clean out governments.So while the TV cameras are focused on Hartlepoolaposs new blue MP, and Sir Keir Starmer weakly reshuffles his uninspiring lieutenants, it may be worth looking at what no-one  is.As of last Thursday, % of the UK population lives in areas controlled by  directly-elected mayors. And  of them are Labour.  The one MP Boris Johnson has just added to his Commons majority will have little power or influence unless she is promoted to a ministerial role. Even then, she would be expected to toe the line, and will be under more financial pressure to do so with whips threatening her with the loss of a government salary. Inidual MPs can cause headaches, make a noise, and fight for their constituents. But their votes are, generally, in the bag for any party leader.Mayors are dferent. They get to spend money. And they can stamp their name on all sorts of things, as the aposBoris bikesapos that were Ken Livingstoneaposs brainchild can attest. That branding has a huge impact on public perception and who voters will put their future faith in.The aposmetro mayorsapos who control more than one local authority have up to £.bn each to spend on capital investment, plus in most cases a right to levy council tax for pet projects. That can buy a lot of votes. There are  such jobs with control over planning, transport, and economic development in their regions, and  of them are held by the Labour Party.  Thereaposs another  elected mayors with power in just one local authority - places like Bedford, Copeland, Lewisham, Mansfield, Middlesbrough and Watford. Only  are held by a party thataposs not red, and only one is blue. All these mayors have dferent powers, but are able to come up with policies on local crime prevention, adult education, early years provision, social services and planning, to name a few. Most can push these policies through council, because it takes a two-thirds majority to oppose them.Perhaps bin collections arenapost top of your agenda butyou start seeing aposMayoraposs Crime Reduction Strategy Preceptapos on your council tax bill, youaposll soon start caring what theyaposre up to. And in a year or two, youaposll know whether your bins, your nanaposs care visits, or your childaposs nursery have improved.Whichaposll be just in time for the next general election. As Prime Minister, Johnsonaposs attention is taken and his hands are tied by Brexit, the union, geopolitics, and his many promises. If he picks a fight with the French over fishing rights, he has to win it. As Mayor of Manchester, Andy Burnham can do whatever the hell he likes, andhe picks a fight with Westminster it doesnapost matterhe wins or loses so long as voters see he was fighting for them.In Bristol, Marvin Rees could spend millions on environmental projects to see off the Greens. In North Tyneside Norma Redfearn can splash out seeding new jobs or training schemes, and be seen to do more to rebuild the Red Wall than any Tory.AndTracy Brabin is replaced as MP for Batley and Spen in the next by-election by a pro-Brexit Conservative, what of it  Sheaposll be Mayor of West Yorkshire, with far more impact, cash, and headlines that will get to local voters, than anyone who spends four days a week in London doing as theyaposre told. The only Westminster power that matters are the very top jobs, and even then itaposs a negotiation. Mayors issue instructions, and can get things done.In  local elections, after three terms of Labour government, the Tories gained  councils including London. Two years later, Margaret Thatcher swept to power. In , Labour took % of the local vote, and in  Tony Blair rode a red wave all the way to Downing Street. The same story is told so often that, when last weekaposs local elections showed the Tories gaining  councils and  councillors while Labour lost  authorities and  councillors, the first reaction was that this boded well for Boris Johnson getting a second term in . But powerful, elected mayors are new. Manchester was the first, in . And they have changed the way that political tea leaves have to be read.

title: who rachel reeves record profile
story: NewsWho is Rachel Reeves  Record and profile of Keir Starmers new Shadow ChancellorThe -year-old long ago dubbed boring snoring is on a mission to inject adrenaline into Keir Starmers frontbench operation. She has the credentials - but will the Labour reshuffle work  We have a look at the le of the Leeds West MPmirrorShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsRachel Reeves is Labours second female shadow chancellor " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get US and UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy notice Labour has a new Shadow Chancellor as the dust settles on Keir Starmer ’s chaotic post-election reshuffle. Rachel Reeves is in after Anneliese Dodds was demoted from Labour ’s second-most-important job after only a year.Many in Labour are furious about the botched shake-up - which the party leader was forced to strip back after a backlash at his bid to remove Angela Rayner as party chair. Ms Rayner now has a -word job title, allowing her allies to claim she was not demoted after all. But all the drama risks overlooking the characters who are now at the top of the party - with Ms Reeves first and foremost. The -year-old has an intriguing political record that enamours her to her fans but angers some on the left. Brought up in Lewisham, south London, she attended a state school and her parents, Sally and Graham, were both teachers. She was the UK’s under- girls’ chess champion and has claimed the game is the perfect preparation for politics. The Leeds West MP did, however, admit in  that she’d played very little since leaving school. Labour runs through her blood - literally. She joined at  and her sister and brother-in-law - Ellie Reeves and John Cryer - are both Labour MPs. She wrote a biography of Labour politician Alice Bacon, published in .  Ms Reeves studied at Oxford and holds a Masters in Economics from the London School of Economics. Fresh out of university she joined the Bank of England - turning down a Goldman Sachs job despite the generous salary. “I believed in public service, and I thought the Bank of England was the best training for an economist,” she has said. She did though move away from the job, working also at Lloyds Banking Group before she became an MP aged  in . “I am one of the few people entering politics to be going to a more popular profession, she joked at the time. She didn’t have a perfect start, mixing up the debt and the deficit in a TV documentary in her first few months.also named her as advertising for unpaid interns in .  But having backed Ed Miliband for leader she enjoyed a quick rise, becoming Chief Secretary to the Treasury after  months. By  she was Shadow Work and Pensions Secretary - where she vowed to be tougher on benefits than the Tories. In comments that still anger the Labour left, she said: “ We would be tougher… If they donapost take it [the offer of a job] they will forfeit their benefit.” She added: If you can work you should be working, and under our compulsory jobs guaranteeyou refuse that job you forgo your benefits, and that is really important. She insisted Labour would scrap the “pernicious” Bedroom Tax but for some her card was marked. Despite enjoying a quick rise, Ms Reeves spent five years in the wilderness of the back benches after the  election.  Having backed Andy Burnham for leader, she did notfrom maternity leave to Jeremy Corbyn ’s Shadow Cabinet.She later backed fierce Corbyn critics Owen Smith and Jess Phillips for leader in  and .Her views on Brexit could be a headache for the leadership.In  she backed a second referendum on the final Brexit deal. But she also said there must be “restrictions” on the free movement of labour. Keir Starmer said in his leadership bid that he’d bring back EU free movement after Brexit. Matt Zarb-Cousin, a former Jeremy Corbyn staffer, said: “Our almost immediate response to losing Hartlepool is to make a Blairite remainer who wanted to stop Brexit the Shadow Chancellor. Wish us luck in Batley [a new by-election] we’re gonna need it.” But her supporters will point to her industrious time holding the worlds of business and government to account. She used her time on the back benches fully, heading up the Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy committee.

title: doctors wrongly removed terrified mums
story: NewsTerried mum who had oies removed at  over cancer risk told it was fibroids after surgeryRebecca Green made the agonising decision to have her oies removed and suffered from surgical menopause, only to be told her suspected cancer was actually endometriosis and fibroidsmirrorShareCommentsByCarol DriverKyle OSullivanTV Features Writer:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsRebecca Green had her oies wrongly removed by doctors " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeRebecca Green feared she was going to die and went through the most terrying and soul destroying time of her le - only to be told doctors had made a massive mistake. The mum-of-two feared was told her crippling stomach pains could be oian cancer and was forced to make an agonising decision that would change her body forever.Rebecca, , had suffered in agony on and off for  years and was told by GPs she had irritable bowel syndrome, but doctors then advised her to have her oies and fallopian tubes removed.Fearing for her le, she sobbed to her husband Adam after getting back from the hospital then spent hours writing emotional goodbye letters to her daughter Ella, , and son Addison, . On what Rebecca refers to as the worst day of my le in November , the part-time HR officer underwent surgery which immediately plunged her body into surgical menopause at the age of . She was completely unprepared for debilitating hot flushes, night sweats, insomnia and crippling fatigue that followed and felt abandoned. However, a month later she was dealt another devastating blow that turned her world upside down once again. Her surgeon called to explain tests showed she had actually been suffering from endometriosis and fibroids - not cancer. I felt as though I had no choice but to have them removed, said Rebecca, who said a newly qualied doctor told her the symptoms could suggest oian cancer. However, he spent less than five minutes discussing surgical menopause. So nothing prepared me for what I was going to face. The day I had my oies removed was the day my world changed forever. It’s been the most dramatic, tearful, terrying and soul destroying time ever. Surgical menopause never ends my bones ache deeply, I get hot like I could pass out andmy HRT patches run out, I can’t get out of bed due to the pain. And now I want to make sure others don’t suffer alone like I did. Rebecca, from Leicester, explained she was advised by her consultant that having her oies and tubes removed was the safest option. I lost my oies to suspected oian cancer but it turned out not to be cancer, she said.  I can’t really think about what could have been, as I can’t live my le that way. I thought I was going to die, I thought I was going to leave behind my kids. My consultant had told me I had complex oian cysts and a high level of CA, which is produced by some oian cancers. Every year , women are diagnosed with oian cancer in the UK, but according to Cancer Research UK there is no test that reliably picks up oian cancer at an early stage. The two tests currently offered by the NHS include for high levels of CA, but this is deemed unreliable as this can be higher for reasons other than cancer. There is also an internal scan, but there is no clear evidence so far that these tests can pick up cancers early and save lives. Rebecca had suffered with painful stomach issues since she was , but GPs told her it was either IBS, cystitis or was being caused by anxiety.  I have been going back and forward to the doctors for decades, said Rebecca, who relied on strong painkillers to ease the pain. I stopped digging and believed what they told me as they kept saying there was nothing really wrong with me. No one mentioned fibroids or endometriosis, yet I was riddled with it. Rebecca fell pregnant at the age of  and then met her husband Adam when she was  in , but she was left in such agony it took over their lives. We moved in together and on the first night, I remember lying on the floor in the house in agony, she said. It got the point that Adam was reluctant to book holidays or special nights out in case I was too ill. He was getting fed up as everyone was saying it was in my head. But as soon as the pain started, I sometimes couldn’t leave the house it was so bad. After falling pregnant with her second child in , Rebecca found herself doubled over in pain and rushed to hospital at eight weeks.  Doctors wrongly told her it was an ectopic pregnancy - but in fact an oian cyst had burst. I’ve never felt anything like it. I was left for  hours believing I’d lost my baby as that’s what they told me. I had to call Adam to tell him. It was horrendous”, Rebecca said. A scan then revealed all the disbursement from the cyst floating around - it had burst - but it wasnapost thoroughly looked into after the birth. Rebecca explained: I was obviously over the moon that the baby was fine, but looking back, I think the fact I had a cyst should have been investigated more. After Addison was born, Rebecca went back to managing her pain with over-the-counter painkillers and all her energy went into looking after her little boy as he was unwell with suspected pneumonia that was later diagnosed as asthma. Rebecca said she had been to the doctors about her stomach pains, but felt as though she was getting nowhere. They kept telling me it was an infection, or I had pulled a muscle but deep down I knew there was something wrong, she added.  Two months before Rebecca and Adam were due to get married in August , she started to experience sharp stabbing pains in the side of her stomach and feared it was her appendix about to burst. I was on the final countdown to my wedding and I was in agony, said the bride-to-be. I had a huge pain in my side, heavy periods and my stomach was huge one minute and down the next. I was worried I wouldn’t fit into my wedding dress, or that I would bleed through it. But my GP told me there was nothing wrong, so I went ahead with the wedding. I was even in pain on my big day. Three weeks later, in August, Rebecca made an appointment to see her GP as she was determined to finally get some answers. A newly qualied doctor told her the symptoms could suggest oian cancer and she was sent for a CA test in September. When the results came back the next day, stunned Rebecca had to make the agonising decision to have her oies removed and she was booked in for surgery at Leicester General Hospital just four weeks later.  I was crying my eyes out on the way down to surgery. I didn’t want to be put to sleep, she heartbreakingly explained. I came round from the anesthesia and was sick and in pain.Then my body went into surgical menopause. I didn’t know anything about it. The HRT was making me really depressed, and I ended up turning to Facebook groups for help.My doctor told me she didn’t know enough about HRT or surgical menopause. I felt abandoned. I had to take my care and health into my own hands. One month later, Rebecca’s surgeon called her to explain tests on her oies had revealed her suspected cancer was actually endometriosis and fibroids. The operation changed my le for the worse, but at least I’m still here. I could have developed cancer next year and maybe it wouldn’t have been caught in time - I can’t think about ‘what s’, she said. Rebecca believes when it comes to aftercare and information about surgical menopause she has been let down by the health system every step of the way. After her devastating ordeal, Rebecca is now raising awareness of what she has been through so other women are more prepared.

title: woman drops six dress sizes
story: NewsWoman drops six dress sizes after seeing le-changing photo on InstagramMarnie McBride, , from Scotland, tried every diet programme going and spent nine years desperately trying to shed the pounds - until she finally found something that worked for hermirrorShareCommentsByZoe ForseyFeatures Editor:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsMarnie had been dieting for years " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeAfter welcoming her beautul twins aged , Marnie McBride decided she wanted to lose weight in order to improve both her physical and mental health. At st and a size , she knew it was time for change but found that while she initially lost weight on a number of popular diet plans it never stayed off for long. Nine years of yo-yo dieting actually saw her gaining st, which impacted her confidence and left her dreading nights out with friends.But after spotting a post from The Munro Method on Instagram Marnie, from Scotland, thought she would give it a go - a decision that has completely changed her le.The programme, which aims to help people lose weight long term with nutritional strategies rather than crash diets worked for Marnie, and sheaposs dropped to st lbs and wears a size . Now , she tells The Mirror: I had just had my twins. Having four kids obviously my body had changed. I wanted to feel a bit better about myself. Other diets didn’t work because they were usually really restrictive, shakes etc, or they taught me nothing about nutrition. So it would be ok for a while when I was doing it but could never stick to it for any period of time and because I hadn’t learned anything then the weight would go back on. It was making me miserable it had totally affected my mental health, I was really anxious and depressed and didn’t really want to go out or see friends. The thought of a night out would me make me anxious all week on the lead up. I was always very sociable, but I started dreading nights out because I was so self-conscious about my weight.  The programme has also seen Marnieaposs entire attitude towards food change, which means sheaposs more confident than ever that it will stick. She explains: “When I joined, I just wanted to lose weight once and for all. I was sick constantly being on a diet. I came across Munro on Instagram. I liked Jasonaposs straight-up attitude. There was no  promises or bulls*** advertising that youaposd lose a stone in a week. I also liked that no foods seemed to be off-limits and that I could fit them into my le rather than it being my whole le. I have  children and a decent social le and previous diets didnapost really accommodate for this.  One of biggest dferences was the community ‘clan munro’ is amazing everyone is so supportive and makes you feel like you’re never alone. “I have a good relationship with food now, I can eat out and know how to fit it into my day or week. I donapost feel guilty about saying yes to cake or takeaways and on the other hand, I also donapost feel guilty when I say no to some things because they donapost align with my goals at that moment in time. My depression has gone, and my anxiety is more or less non-existent. Iaposve gone from sleeping all day to walking - thousand steps a day and I found a love for the gym.  I accept my body and love it for what it has done, and I genuinely have so much confidence now. I went from wearing baggy clothes to wearing sports bras and booty shorts. I feel like a much more positive and content person. I’ve been so inspired by the amazing work that Jason does that I’ve now embarked on my own journey to become a coach and help others. On the new programme Marnie lost lbs in a year and a half, but she wasnapost aposdietingapos throughout. She gave herself breaks to live her le, making sure she allowed herself freedom to enjoy herself on holiday and at Christmas.

title: airlines scramble add extra flights
story: NewsAirlines scramble to add extra flights as Brits rush to book holidays with Portugal topTheres been a surge in interest in holidays to Portugal with the likes of easyJet and Ryanair adding thousands of extra seats to flights, while Google searches have skyrocketedmirrorShareCommentsByRyan MerrieldReporter:,  MAY NewsPortugal is topping the list for holiday favourites among travel-starved Brits " %, rgba, rgba, url"Fancy an escape to the Chill newsletter for weekly inspiration and advice on UK holidays Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.Sign Up!When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeAirlines are scrambling to add extra flights to meet soaring demand for holidays in the days after the green list announcement. On Friday, UK Transport Secretary Grant Shapps revealed the  countries where two week quarantine for those ing to England will no longer be necessary as of May .It included holiday favourite Portugal, which is now topping bookings and Google searches. The surge in interest prompted easyJet to add , seats, as well as restart a route from Newcastle to Faro in south Portugal. While Ryanair added , to the likes of the Algarve, Lisbon and Porto for the summer holidays.Thomas Cook said it had taken more bookings for trips to the European sun trap in one hour than the whole of last month. The firmaposs head of PR David Child said jet-setters appeared posed, ready and waiting to go as Mr Shapps announced the relaxing of restrictions at the Downing Street briefing.Have your holiday plans been affected by the pandemic  Let us know at webnews@mirrorAnd data from Jet and Jetholidaysshows that summer  bookings to Faro in the Algarve and Madeira increased by more than  percent in the  hours after the briefing - and over , percent when compared to the same period one week ago.According to portertravel, online searches skyrocketed by over , percent in the  minutes after the announcement. Gary Piazzon, founder of portertravel, praised the announcement, describing Portugal as the real winner here. Speaking to the Sun, he said: “Data reveals that in the last hour, Google searches for ‘Holidays to Portugal’ have skyrocketed, up ,% when compared with ten minutes before the Transport Secretary’s announcement.Mr Piazzon said that searches for fellow green listers Israel and Gibraltar were also up ,% and %, respectively.

title: british expats being refused covid
story: NewsBritish expats are being refused Covid vaccines in Spain due to BrexitBritish expats claim they are being turned away for Covid vaccines by local health centres, with one saying he was told "go away, we don’t vaccinate foreigners". The Spanish Health Ministry said the jabs are open to all residentsmirrorShareCommentsByRyan MerrieldReporter:,  MAY NewsHealth centres are turning away British expats for vaccines, despite government orders, it has been claimed " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeBritish expats living in Spain are being refused Covid vaccines despite the countryaposs government extending the roll-out to all residents, it has been claimed.Local authorities are said to be turning away foreigners who donapost have public health cards, with the Brexit Withdrawal Agreement specying non-nationals must get private health insurance instead.The Spanish Health Ministry has, however, repeatedly made it clear the jabs are to be equally accessible to everyone living in the country. Expat John McKenzie, who has diabetes and a heart condition, said he has been stopped from registering at his local health centre in El Sauzal, Tenere, four times since vaccinations got underway.The -year-old told the Daily: The first time they said they cannot register people on private insurance for the vaccine in the absence of any instruction from the Canarian government.Go away, we don’t vaccinate foreigners, Mr McKenzie said he was told at one stage. “It’s very frightening not being able to have the vaccine when you have health conditions like I do.Have you been turned away for a vaccine in Spain  Let us know at webnews@mirrorKate Harmond, who moved from Brighton to Lanzarote, said her and her husband, both in their s, were initially turned away by a health centre in Arrece. We had an appointment, but when we got there they said that we couldn’t have the vaccine as we did not have a public health card, she told the newspaper. After showing every single possible document you can imagine to prove residency they were eventually given a jab, she added.  A spokesperson for the Spanish Health Ministry told the : It is the regional governments who are in charge of the vaccination programme. It comes after Spain was included on Englandaposs amber list for travel when the border re-opens on May , meaning holidaymakers will not be exempt from quarantining on .

title: delivery mans rapid covid test
story: AdvertorialDelivery mans rapid Covid test outside hospice could have saved livesRegular rapid testing at home is a quick and easy way to help stop the spread of Covid- and protect the people around youmirrorShareByLaura Tait:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY AdvertorialRegular testing now seen as vital to stop the spread of Covid-Alex had no symptoms when he tested positive for Covid- back in February. Around a third of people with coronavirus show no symptoms, so can infect others without even knowing they’ve been ill. Rapid testing is a vital tool to make sure people know when to self isolate so they break the chain of transmission. Alex, , from Hemel Hempstead, works for JamVans, a removal company that provides Covid- tests for its employees. He was experiencing no symptoms at all when he tested positive for Covid. “We move people’s homes on a daily basis, and also have a delivery contract with a local hospice – it has about  charity stores, and we help them move all the stock,” says Alex. “One morning before work I did a rapid Covid- test outside the hospice, then sat in my van waiting for the results. I’d done a few of these tests, and thought it would be fine as I didn’t have a single symptom – but then the test came back positive.”  “I spoke to the hospice on the phone from outside the building, and they told me I had to go for a PCR test. My company booked me in with a private firm and I went straight there. Our company policy is that we have to wear a mask in people’s houses and throughout our offices, and I stick to the guidelines as much as I can, so at first I thought the rapid flow test must be wrong. But within an hour, I was told I definitely had Covid. I couldn’t quite believe it.” Alex was able to isolate straightaway, ensuring he wasn’t spreading Covid to any vulnerable people he came into contact with. “I stopped working to self-isolate on full pay, and still didn’t develop any symptoms at all,” he says. “Without the test, I definitely would have carried on working, which is why it’s so important to have regular tests, evenyou haven’t got any symptoms. I had the virus and I felt fine, but imagineI’d given it to my parents, my grandparents or my colleagues  “If I’m driving between  charity shops, with three or four people in each shop, I could have been quite a spreader. I would have put a lot of people at risk, who may not be as young and healthy as I am – you never know who you’re passing it on to. It might sound dramatic, but in my case, taking the test could have saved lives. I haven’t had the jab yet, but I will as soon as I can – and I’ll still be taking two tests a week.Get into the testing habit More than half the adults in the UK have had at least one dose of Covid vaccination and lockdown restrictions are beginning to ease. But the virus is still out there and around a third of all the people who are infected do not show any symptoms. Regular rapid testing is vital to break the chain of transmission – now all adults are advised to do two tests a week. Rapid testing kits are free and you can do them at home, with results appearing within just  minutes. If you test positive, you’ll be able to isolate straightaway rather than risk spreading Covid to others. Millions of people have already made regular home testing part of their routine, as secondary school children and their parents have been able get free tests since February, but now everyone is encouraged to play their part. Every test helps to put your mind at rest and helps protect people around you as the country moves out of lockdown. Around one in three people with coronavirus has no symptoms. Rapid Covid-tests are for people who aren’t showing symptoms. If you’re showing symptoms , order a PCR test. Test twice a week, or every three or four days: it’s the best way to catch a case of Covid- at the point it becomes highly infectious.If you test positive you should self-isolate immediately and visit nhs.uk get-tested or call  to order a PCR test that will confirm the result.If you test negative, you must still follow the Hands, Face, Space and Fresh Air rules to minimise the spread of Covid-. Rapid tests are easy to use and give results within  minutes. It’s important to report your results online straightaway, whether the test is positive, negative or even void. It’s easy to do at gov.uk report-covid-result or by calling .More than m rapid tests have been taken since October , and hundreds of thousands of positive cases among people with no symptoms have been picked up. Information from the rapid tests is kept anonymous, and scientists use it to spot patterns and outbreaks more quickly and accurately, helping to reduce the risk of future lockdowns. Even though you might have already had one or two doses of vaccine, there’s a chance you could still give Covid to someone , as no vaccine is  per cent effective. So it’s vital to test twice weekly as well as continuing to follow social distancing guidance, washing hands, wearing a face covering and letting fresh air in. Rapid Covid- tests are suitableyou have no symptoms of Covid .“Remember, around a third of people with coronavirus have no symptoms, but could be spreading it to others without knowing,” says GP Dr Amir Khan. “Rapid testing is effective at detecting people who are infectious and enabling us to find Covid- cases that we otherwise would not know about. This helps us in our efforts to stop the spread of the virus. Testing regularly even when you have no symptoms means we can keep infection levels low and our country safe, and the good thing is they give a result within  minutes.” And, as Dr Khan notes, the tests are very reliableyou do them correctly. “Testing ourselves for coronavirus using rapid Covid- tests is vital in keeping ourselves and others safe from coronavirus and keeping infection rates in our communities low. When done correctly, the tests are at least . per cent specic, which means the risk of  positives is extremely low – less than one in a thousand. This means it is a very good test.”‘All I had was a mild sore throat’ Kim Tobin, from Southend, Essex, works in a supermarket and had a positive Covid- test in January  Routine rapid testing in the workplace helped Kim, , discover she had Covid, even though she was showing no symptoms. Without the test, she could have spread it to her workmates and customers.“I had a very, very mild sore throat, just a little scratch and that was it,” she says. “I didn’t even think anything of it. I was all dressed for work, ready to go. Then I went and had the test, and after  minutes the lady who had done it came up to me and said, ‘You need to go home right now because you’ve got it – you’ve tested positive.’”

title: everything you need know covid
story: NewsEverything you need to know about Covid vaccine passports - including how to get oneDespite much speculation, Transport Secretary Grant Shapps confirmed at Fridays Downing Street briefing the NHS Covid app will be ready for use from May mirrorShareCommentsByRyan MerrieldReporter:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsCovid vaccine passports are set to be ready for when the borders open on May  after much speculation " %, rgba, rgba, url"Fancy an escape to the Chill newsletter for weekly inspiration and advice on UK holidays Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.Sign Up!When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeSome level of Covid passport will be needed for those looking to travel abroad from the UK this summer once the ban on non-essential foreign travel is lted in a week. After some doubt, the NHS app will be ready to be used as digital proof a passenger has been inoculated from when borders open on May , Transport Secretary Grant Shapps confirmed on Friday.The minister also revealed the  countries where -day quarantine can be avoided, which included holiday favourite Portugal, leading to a surge in bookings. As such, the appaposs developers NHSX are now racing against time to ensure the finishing touches are added. Downing Street has also confirmed the app would satisfy the entry requirements of multiple countries, including Greece and Spain, which were placed on the amber list. Greece has even said Brits can use the NHS card given out at their vaccination appointments to confirm their status, meaning those who have had two doses wonapost need a negative PCR test.This is despite an investigation finding almost identical fake cards are being sold online for as little as £, sparking fears travellers could use them to cheat their way on holiday. Below is everything you need to know about Covid vaccine passportsHow will the digital passport work  The Transport Secretary was adamant the NHS app could be altered in time to add a vaccine passportby next Monday. He said: If needed, people in England who have both vaccine doses will be able to demonstrate their Covid vaccination status via the NHS app from May . How exactly it will work is not been made clear - but there are two smartphone-compatible prototypes that could give us an idea. First is the Travel Pass, created by Iata, the International Air Transport Association. Second, is the EUaposs Green Certicate, which has already been agreed for use in multiple European nations and includes a QR code - though is still in the development stage. The NHS passport would work similar to a boarding pass, though whether a code would be scanned like the EU version has not been confirmed. Mr Shapps would not comment on whether the UK would be joining up with the EU and or Iata and it remains unclear how each app would integrate data. However, a Transport spokesman later said: We are working on a solution to enable residents to prove their Covid- status, including vaccination status, to other countries on the outbound leg. We are working on this as a priority and intend to have the solution ready as soon as possible.  WhatI donapost have access to the app  Mr Shapps said: Those without access to the app can request a letter from the NHS proving their vaccination status by calling , from  May. Such a document would likely be similar to a physical Yellow Fever vaccine certicate. But it appears it canapost be accessed prior to the day the border re-opens and how long it would take to arrive by post is unclear. Both the Iata and Digital Green Certicate will also offer paper versions.  How do I get a vaccine passport  If all goes to plan and you have a smartphone, you should be able to just download the NHS app or download an updateyou already have it. It would presumably then gain access to your NHS profile and number to determine whether youaposve had a jab or not. There has been some speculation that those who have been vaccinated and given a physical card may need to input a number into the app as a way of downloading medical records securely. The Iata and EU versions are both also free to download. The former has been trialled by at least  airlines, including British Airways, Singapore Airlines and Etihad, and appears to be the global choice.

title: family beautiful mum 33 who
story: NewsFamily of beautul mum, , who died in crash on M say le has stood stillNatalie Doherty, , lost control of her car on the M near Bury, Greater Manchester - she leaves behind her six-year-old son BobbymirrorShareCommentsByPaige Oldfield:,  MAY NewsNatalie Doherty with six-year-old son Bobby " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeThe grieving family of a “beautul” mum who died in a crash on the M say “le has stood still”. Natalie Doherty, , lost control of her vehicle on the motorway near Bury on Saturday afternoon. She had just joined the road when her car hit floodwater, aquaplaned, left the carriageway and crashed into a tree. Tragically, she was pronounced dead at the scene, leaving behind her six-year-old son Bobby.Speaking to the Manchester Evening News, family members have said it doesnapost feel real.She hasn’t lived her le, they said, heartbroken. Last night, Natalie’s mother, Marion Mckenzie, lay awake clutching a photo of her only child. The family said they “just knew” something was wrong when they didn’t hear from her for several hours.  Then, at .pm, they received a phone call that would change their lives forever. Speaking to the MEN, Marion described the moment she found out her daughter had died. The -year-old became emotional as she said: “I screamed and Bobby said, ‘What’s wrong with nana ’ “We told him I had stubbed my toe. “Then Bobby sat on his bed with his McDonald’s watching telly.  “This morning, I realised we will never see her again. “We will never speak to her. “You just think to yourself, why did she have to go  Why didn’t she just stay at home  Why didn’t they go in the van  “But you could question everything.” Her inconsolable family have since come together to pay tribute to the “stunning” mum-of-one, who they say had a “heart of gold”. “Le has been horrendous. It’s like le has stood still,” Marion’s partner, Andrea Mckenzie, said. “Time has stopped and it’s not real. “I can’t imagine what Marion is going through. It’s her only child. “She hasn’t lived her le. She hasn’t lived her le with Bobby – and you should never have to bury your own children. “Marion just lay there with tears streaming down her face. She didn’t even shut her eyes. “She just had a picture of Natalie and herself in her hands, clutching it, and there’s nothing I can do.”  Natalie had grown up in Haslingden in Rossendale but lived in Crawshawbooth near Rawtenstall at the time of her death. She had attended secondary school in Rochdale before going on to work as a dental nurse for  years, her latest job being a receptionist at a dental practice. Her family say she loved food, shopping and visiting beauty salons, but most of all being a mother to her young son. Bobby was meant to be travelling in the car with Natalie at the time of the crash but wanted to stay at his grandmother’s house instead. Andrea continued: “He’s six – his dad told him mummy is an angel and that god only takes the good angels. “I’ve never seen a bond like the bond with her and Bobby they were absolutely inseparable. “She said she would pick Bobby up but he wanted to stay with his nana, thank God. “We didn’t hear anything because she usually rings to FaceTime with Bobby. “We didn’t hear anything and we just knew. “It got to pm and we knew something wasn’t quite right. At .pm we got the phone call.” Natalie’s cousin, Debra Wainwright, described her passing as a “massive loss”. She said: “I was brought up with Natalie and she’s more like a sister to me than a cousin. “She was really close to my mum and loved going to aunty Ann’s for a Sunday lunch. “We are a very close-knit family and it’s a massive, massive loss.” The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.

title: ferries more covid safe holidaymakers
story: NewsFerries are more Covid safe for holidaymakers than flying, says industry bossBrittany Ferries CEO Christophe Mathieu said Brits should consider going on holidays abroad via ferry than having to go through crowded airports where there is more chance of spreading CovidmirrorShareCommentsByRyan MerrieldReporter:,  MAY NewsTravelling via ferry rather than aeroplane is more Covid safe, a travel boss has suggested " %, rgba, rgba, url"Fancy an escape to the Chill newsletter for weekly inspiration and advice on UK holidays Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.Sign Up!When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeHolidaymakers should be looking to travel by ferry rather than fly from airports where thereaposs more chance of spreading Covid, an industry boss has suggested. Thereaposs been a huge surge in bookings after Downing Street on Friday announced its green list of  countries where quarantine can be avoided onto England from May .It included holiday favourite Portugal, which is now topping bookings and Google searches. The rise in interest prompted easyJet to add , seats, as well as restart a route from Newcastle to Faro in south Portugal. While Ryanair added , to the likes of the Algarve, Lisbon and Porto for the summer holidays.Thomas Cook said it had taken more bookings for trips to the European sun trap in one hour than the whole of last month after the briefing. Have your holiday plans been affected by the pandemic  Let us know at webnews@mirror  But experts are warning holidaymakers they face unavoidable -hour delays in UK airports for the rest of the year.Mammoth queues are already being caused at the likes of Heathrow Airport due to Covid-related checks as the UK battles to prevent mutant strains coming into the country. And this is before overseas travel gets the formal go-ahead.  Brittany Ferries CEO Christophe Mathieu has urged travellers to consider going abroad via ferry instead. We want to remind people that there are attractive alternatives to air travel this summer, he said. Taking the ferry means there’s no need to mingle in a busy terminal building, or arrivals hall, alongside passengers from multiple destinations.

title: first picture kind caring mum
story: NewsFirst picture of kind and caring mum, , killed in house fire as daughter pays tributeMum-of-three Michelle Howie, who died in a house fire in Sedgley in Dudley, West Midlands, was an "amazing mother" and a "rock" for her husband, her devastated daughter saysmirrorShareCommentsBySophie WheelerChris KitchingSenior News Reporter:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY News with her husband Shaun and daughter Demi" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _michelle-howie.jpg"Michelle Howiewith her husband Shaun and daughter Demi " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy notice The daughter of a woman killed in a house fire has told how her mum will be dearly missed in a heartbreaking tribute to her.The -year-old woman, named locally as Michelle Howie, died and a -year-old girl was seriously injured in the blaze in Dudley, West Midlands, on Saturday afternoon. The teenage girl remains in hospital with serious injuries. A -year-old man was taken to hospital but was released a short while later after being checked over, said police. Ms Howie was an amazing mother to her three children and a rock for her husband Shaun, who was involved in the fire, said her devastated daughter Beth Simcox. Ms Simcox said: She was an amazing mother to all three of her children. She was my dadaposs rock and they were incredible together. No matter what le threw at my mum she always had a way of figuring it out. We are all going to miss her dearly especially her mum in Scotland and my dad Shaun. With everything going on we would appreciate some privacy to come together as a family to grieve her death. West Midlands Police said officers were called to the house fire in Sedgley at around .pm on Saturday. A spokesperson said a woman was declared dead at the scene. The circumstances surrounding the fire are being investigated by police. Detective Inspector Carla Thompson said: “We are working closely with the fire service to determine what happened. I would urge anyone with information to get in touch. “Our thoughts are with the family of the woman at this dficult time, who are being supported by specialist officers.” The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. title: holidays blow rapid free tests
story: NewsHolidays blow as rapid free tests may not be enough proof for ing BritsBookings to a number of countries, including Portugal, have soared after a green list of  countries where UK travellers can go to without quarantine was revealedmirrorShareCommentsByWilliam WalkerNews Reporter:,  MAY NewsForeign travel will be allowed again from May  " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeSun-seeking tourists have been dealt a blow after reports claim free lateral flow tests may not be approved for travellers ing from green list countries. Bookings to a number of countries, including Portugal, have soared after a green list of  countries where UK travellers can go to without quarantine was revealed. But Brits ing to England will still have to show a negative Covid test taken up to  hours before travel. Whitehall sources had previously said that travellers will be given free lateral flow tests to pack in their suitcase for thejourney. Now, the Dailyreports that the free testing equipment may not now be allowed for use by May  after a failure to reach “cross-Government agreement” on the scheme. It comes amid concerns about validating the test results which are self-administered by travellers as well as their accuracy. A source was reported to have said: “It is more about the implementation than the science. How do you check the results  How do you validate them  Do people just turn up and show them ” A Department for Transport spokesman was reported to have said it was “working with the travel industry and private testing providers ahead of international travel reopening, to see how we can further reduce the cost of travel for the British public, while ensuring travel is as safe as possible.

title: indian south african covid variants
story: NewsIndian or South African Covid iants could overtake to become dominant in UKScientists responsible for monitoring for mutant Covid- in Britain have discovered that the Indian iant can spread “at least” as well as the Kent iant which is currently the dominant strainmirrorShareCommentsByMartin BagotHealth and Science editor:,  MAY NewsExperts say the Indian or South African iant could become dominant " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeIndian or South African iants could overtake to become dominant in the UK, scientists have warned. Experts responsible for monitoring for mutant Covid- in Britain have discovered that the Indian iant can spread “at least” as well as the Kent iant currently dominant.Known officially as B..., cases of the Indian iant in the UK have grown from  to  in a week, mostly in Bolton and London.Almost half are related to travel from abroad.The Covid- Genomics UK Consortiumsaid there is a “possibility” it could take over in Britain but that vaccines would drastically reduce severe cases and deaths. COG-UK member Prof Ravi Gupta, of Cambridge University, said: “Yes there is a possibility [it could become dominant]. “We have very low transmission in the UK so there is an opening for a virus that is better adapted to vaccinated people to start transmitting. “It won’t cause severe disease in the majority of people or death. But it could become the thing that circulates. So could the South African iant.” Britain has one of the best genetic sequencing groups in the world able to quickly identy new Covid- iants and how dangerous they are. It comes as the world’s second-most populous country is coming under pressure to completely lockdown as the Indian iant wreaks havoc. Prime Minister Narendra Modi is facing growing calls for draconian restrictions after India suffered . million confirmed infections and , deaths. Hospitals are running out of oxygen and beds while morgues and crematoria are full. From coronavirus to Brexit, our daily politics newsletter is there to guide you these turbulent times. The newsletter is sent out twice daily with the latest UK  world politics news, along with leading opinion and analysis.You can sign up here.

Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeTo mark the start of Mental Health Awareness Week, the British Asian Trust and CareTech Foundation are jointly urging the British-Pakistani population to recognise and de-stigmatise mental health within their communities. I wholly support this initiative. With my own Asian background, I have experienced first-hand the devastating affect mental health has on people when it is a taboo subject – misunderstood, ignored and brushed under the carpet. We cannot allow this situation to carry on because not recognising the importance of mental health has a wider impact on all society. My parents and countless other first-generation British Pakistanis grew up in a culture that doesn’t acknowledge mental health. I remember my own trauma when I realised I might be made to marry someone my parents chose for me. What do you think  Have your say in comments below  It consumed my thoughts as an -year-old. I couldn’t talk to my parents about it because they would have been ashamed of me, and I couldn’t talk to my teachers and friends because they didn’t understand my culture. So I had no outlet for those feelings of fear, anxiety, anger and helplessness. Shockingly, in Pakistan, families often turn to spiritual healers, who associate mental illness with supernatural forces such as witchcraft, possession and black magic.  A child showing signs of misbehaviour or a woman not adhering to the cultural norms would be taken to one of these healers to rid them of the “gin” or evil spirit. The UK has accessible mental health services with more than , registered therapy professionals. Yet many in the UK’s Pakistani communities don’t reach out for help for fear of judgement. In one UK study, middle-aged Pakistani men and older Indian and Pakistani women reported signicantly higher rates of depression than white people. It angers me that the western-educated Pakistani Prime Minister Imran Khan has not used his  to address the mental health of his population, which could in turn have a positive impact on the Asian community here in the UK. title: lorry driver used phone place
story: NewsLorry driver used phone to place bet on gambling app minutes before killing dad-of-twoDean Moffat, , has been jailed for seven years at Winchester Crown Court after he killed a dad-of-two when he crashed into him just minutes after betting £ on a greyhound racemirrorShareCommentsByMirror:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsDean Moffat has been jailed for seven years over his dangerous driving while led to the tragic killing of the dad-of-two " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA lorry driver who killed a dad-of-two when he cannoned into his car just minutes after placing a bet on a gambling app has been jailed. Dean Moffat, , bet £ on a greyhound race less than two minutes before ploughing into Ric Mboma, from west London, on the A near Winchester at :pm on November , . Mr Mboma, , was with his two teenage kids at the side of a dual carriageway when the crash occurred and he was instantly killed. His car had broken down and he was seeking to replace a tyre when Moffat smashed into him, causing his car to spiral through the air, Winchester Crown Court heard.Army veteran Moffat, of Peterlee, County Durham, had almost continually used his iPhone during his long journey across the UK by as he took to Facebook  times, read  emails and five WhatsApp messages, took two calls and made another.He also frequently used his firmaposs tracking app and placed four bets amid a flurry of activity on betting apps, placing £, £ on greyhound races. Dashcam footage revealed Moffat could have seen Mr Mbomaaposs hazard lights  seconds before the crash and had seven seconds of unobstructed vision before his MAN lorry smashed into the Toyota Corolla at mph. Other vehicles had braked and changed lane to avoid Mr Mboma but Moffat - who was on cruise control and repeatedly veered onto the rumble strips - took no evasive action.  The HGV driver - who brazenly told police using his phone does not distract him - deleted betting apps Sky Bet and Bet  minutes after the crash in a bid to cover up his crimes. Moffat, who claimed to have a gambling addiction, initially told police he deleted the apps so he didnapost see the football scores coming through as notications. Mr Mbomaaposs children, Heaven, , and Witley,  both suffered lasting physical and mental injuries. Judge Jane Miller QC condemned Moffat, an Royal Logistics Corps Sergeant with  years service, and jailed him for seven years. He said: This was driving that decided to ignore the rules for a prolonged time. There was a total disregard for the great danger that was caused to others on many occasions.  You took no evasive action whatsoever and cannoned straight into Mr Mboma, causing his death instantly. You were uninjured, your phone was not seized immediately, and you knew exactly what you were doing when less than  minutes later you uninstalled betting apps. The dascham footage shows exactly what happened,you had not been looking at your phone you would have had ample time to take evasive action. You were on your mobile phone for a signicant amount of time on your journey that afternoon. I have no doubt your failure to realise your own danger constituted an extreme risk to other road users, especially as when you were driving what is essentially a lethal weapon.  Using your phone meant you were seriously distracted. You continue to make excuses by pretending not to knowyou were placing bets. This was a prolonged, persistent and deliberate case of bad driving, using a phone is a gross and avoidable distraction. Mr Mboma was unavoidably on the road and was vulnerable and so were his children. Mr Mbomaaposs daughter Witley, now , read out harrowing victim impact statements on behalf of her traumatised family. She suffered a double break in her arm while her brother suffered a broken leg and has lasting joint pain. Witley, who had to drop out of university due to the trauma, said: I canapost help but blame myself for my fatheraposs demise and suffer with survivoraposs guilt.

title: michael stone could cleared russell
story: NewsMichael Stone could be cleared of Russell murders as police find lost evidenceA bootlace which was said to have been lost  years ago was discovered at a police station and is due to undergo forensic testing. Michael Stones lawyers believe it could clear him of the murders of Lin and Megan RussellmirrorShareByRyan MerrieldReporter:,  MAY NewsMichael Stone was originally convicted of the Russell murders in  " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeThe man convicted of Lin and Megan Russellaposs murders, Michael Stone, could be cleared after police found lost evidence  years later, it has been claimed. A bootlace retrieved from the scene in Chillenden, Kent, in , and then misplaced has now been rediscovered and DNA tests could prove Stone, , was not guilty. The prisoner has always denied committing the killings of mum Lin, , and her youngest daughter Megan, six, as well as the attempted murder of her sister Josie, then nine. The latter was found with le-threatening head injuries but miraculously survived. The three were attacked on a country lane as they walked home from a swimming gala on July , . Stone was arrested the following year before being convicted at Maidstone Crown Court.  Barrister Mark McDonald told The Sun: For  years police have been denying they had the lace, and now at long last they’ve found it.Michael Stone is hopeful the DNA tests will lead to the real perpetrator being found. The bootlace had been used to tie up one of the girls and left at the scene by the killer.  In , six segments of the lace were used for DNA testing but results came back inconclusive. In , Stone, of Gillingham, was convicted for a second time during a retrial after a prisoner who gave evidence retracted his statement. After a further appeal was rejected in , Stoneaposs lawyers requested the remaining section of lace be tested in , with DNA techniques having progressed considerably.  Mr McDonald said the legal team waited three years for police to respond and said they didnapost have the lace, claiming it hadnapost been ed by Forensic Science Service in . But the lab insisted they had sent it back. Police then kept saying the lace had been tested to destruction, he added. The Criminal Cases Review Commissionbegan probing the convictions in  and were given the previously tested segments but not the missing cm piece.  In , Kent Police said the lace wasnapost lost but only fibrous strands remained after testing. In October , Mr McDonald was then told by the CCRC the lace had been found at a police station. However, the lawyer said there are concerns it could have been forensically contaminatedit wasnapost kept securely. He said the CCRC are now testing the lace.  The review commission had also previously requested a lunchbox which had been found at the scene and contained a bloody fingerprint. However, it was told it had also been misplaced. A further review had been launched in  when serial killer Levi Bellfield confessed to the murders before retracting it. During the CCRCaposs review, it has previously not found evidence of failures in the way the case had been originally investigated and never referred to the Court of Appeal. In a statement sent to the Mirror, Detective Chief Superintendent Paul Fotheringham of Kent Police said: We are aware that the Criminal Cases Review Commission is considering an application from Michael Stone appealing his conviction for the murders of Lin and Megan Russell and the attempted murder of Josie Russell in .
